note.text: Fatal ST-elevation myocardial infarction at age 55. Was a heavy smoker (2 packs/day for 30 years) with uncontrolled hypertension and high cholesterol. Refused lifestyle modifications and irregular medication compliance.
Hypertension diagnosed at age 45. Poorly controlled with systolic pressures often >180 mmHg. Non-compliant with medications and lifestyle recommendations.
Sudden cardiac death from massive myocardial infarction at age 60. Known to have chest pain episodes but never sought medical care. Heavy smoker and worked in physically demanding job.
Hypertension diagnosed at age 50 during routine screening. Well-controlled with ACE inhibitor (enalapril 10mg daily). Regular monitoring and good medication compliance.
High cholesterol diagnosed 10 years ago. Managed with atorvastatin 20mg daily and dietary modifications. LDL maintained <100 mg/dL with treatment.

Recently diagnosed with hypertension at age 34 during pre-employment physical. Started on lifestyle modifications and lisinopril 5mg daily. Concerned about family history and working on smoking cessation.
Urgent coronary angiography to evaluate extent of coronary artery disease following positive stress test
Evaluate left ventricular function and wall motion abnormalities
Comprehensive smoking cessation program including behavioral counseling and pharmacotherapy options
Supervised exercise program and cardiac diet education following angiography results

dosageInstruction.text: 40mg orally once daily in the evening

reasonCode.text: Post-angiography follow-up and treatment plan discussion

text.div: Chest pain and palpitations during exercise at gym

40-year-old Saudi male engineer reports substernal chest pressure during moderate exercise at gym, particularly during treadmill running. Pain rated 6/10, radiates to left arm, associated with shortness of breath and palpitations. Symptoms resolve with rest after 5-10 minutes. No symptoms at rest. Recently started intensive fitness program. Smokes 1 pack/day for 15 years (15 pack-year history). Strong family history of premature cardiovascular disease - father had fatal MI at age 55, paternal grandfather died from MI at age 60.

Vital Signs: BP 138/85 mmHg (stage 1 hypertension), HR 75 bpm regular, afebrile. BMI: 28.5 (overweight). Cardiac exam reveals normal S1/S2, no murmurs, gallops, or rubs. Stress ECG shows ST-segment depression in lateral leads (V4-V6) at 85% max heart rate, consistent with ischemia. Laboratory: Total cholesterol 240 mg/dL (high), LDL 165 mg/dL (high), HDL 35 mg/dL (low), triglycerides calculated. Cardiac troponin I negative.

1. Stable angina pectoris with positive stress test (ICD-10: I20.9)
2. High cardiovascular risk profile including:
- Current tobacco use disorder (15 pack-year history)
- Dyslipidemia (elevated total cholesterol, LDL; low HDL)
- Stage 1 hypertension
- Family history of premature coronary artery disease
- Overweight (BMI 28.5)
3. Likely significant coronary artery disease requiring angiographic evaluation
4. No evidence of acute coronary syndrome (negative troponin)

Medications:

  • Aspirin 81mg daily (cardioprotection)
  • Atorvastatin 40mg daily (lipid management, target LDL <100 mg/dL)
  • Metoprolol 25mg twice daily (heart rate control, anti-ischemic effect)

Diagnostic Orders:

  • Urgent coronary angiography to evaluate extent of coronary artery disease
  • Echocardiogram to assess LV function and wall motion

Referrals/Education:

  • Smoking cessation counseling (priority intervention)
  • Cardiac rehabilitation program pending angiography results

Follow-up:

  • Angiography scheduled within 2 weeks
  • Cardiology follow-up post-procedure for treatment planning
  • No strenuous exercise until cleared by cardiology

Lifestyle Modifications:

  • Immediate smoking cessation
  • Cardiac diet (low sodium, low saturated fat)
  • Gradual exercise program under supervision
  • Weight management (target BMI <25)

Significant family history of premature cardiovascular disease. Father suffered fatal myocardial infarction at age 55, was a heavy smoker with uncontrolled hypertension. Paternal grandfather also died from heart attack at age 60. Mother (65 years) has well-controlled hypertension and high cholesterol. Younger brother (35 years) recently diagnosed with hypertension. Strong pattern of cardiovascular risk factors including smoking, hypertension, and early cardiac events in male lineage, indicating genetic predisposition requiring aggressive risk factor modification.
